Message.body:
Hi John,

 

For all the reasons we articulated at the meeting we are sticking with our position that Ms. Beers does not meet the minimum qualifications for Probation Division Director I. Any next steps from this point would be up to you.  Thanks.

Importance: High

 

Mr. DeBoer:


Per The County of San Bernardino Personnel Rules, Rule IV, Section 20, my client, Ms. Amy Newcomb, would like to appeal the August 19, 2015, rejection of her Application for Division Director I based on not meeting the minimum qualifications (please see the below).
Per Personnel Rules, Rule IV, Section 20, the client has until September 4, 2015, to resolve this complaint.  in the interim, my client and I are willing and able to meet to discuss the above, and attached.  I note that we have a similar meeting scheduled on September 2, 2015.  Can we handle this at the same time?  Please advise.


Thank you for your time and consideration.

-----Original Message----- From: gmcintyre <gmcintyre@hr.sbcounty.gov> To: Amynewcomb14 <Amynewcomb14@aol.com> Sent: Wed, Aug 19, 2015 7:48 am Subject: Probation Division Director I









August 19, 2015

Amy Newcomb 9416 Encina Ave Fontana, CA 92335

RE: Probation Division Director I
Dear Applicant:
Thank you for seeking employment with the County of San Bernardino. We regret to inform you that, based on the information you provided, you do not meet the minimum requirements for this position.

Please visit our website at www.sbcounty.gov/hr for other employment opportunities. Note however, you may not re-apply for this position for a period of six (6) months.


We appreciate your interest in this employment opportunity with the County of San Bernardino and wish you the best in your job search.


Sincerely,


County of San Bernardino
Human Resources Department

Message.subject: RE: Send data from MFP11272663 09/18/2015 17:32

Message.body:
Hi John,

 

Our responses are below.

 

Specifically, we are trying to figure out how does a need for a list come into being?

The need for a list comes into being when the Department makes the decision to fill a vacant position.

 

What are the qualifications?

Probation Officer I:

Option 1: Completion of a bachelor's degree or equivalent coursework from a college or university accredited by any accrediting association recognized by the United Stated Department of Education. No experience required.

Applications will also be accepted from candidates currently enrolled and completing their last semester/quarter prior to graduating with a Bachelor's degree. A letter from the school indicating graduation date must be submitted with the application. Proof of degree conferred must be provided at time of hire.

--OR--

Option 2: Thirty (30) semester (45 quarter) units of completed college coursework in psychology, sociology, administration of justice, or other closely related behavioral science; at least half of the required coursework must be upper division. No experience required.

Note: Applicants that do not possess a bachelor's degree must provide copies of transcripts (preferred) or a list of completed college coursework. Qualifying degrees or coursework must be completed at a college or university accredited by any accrediting association recognized by the United States Department of Education.

Degrees or coursework completed outside of the U.S. must be accompanied by an evaluation report from a reputable credential evaluation service indicating equivalency to degrees or coursework completed at a college or university accredited by any accrediting association recognized by the United States Department of Education.

 

 

Probation Officer II:

Option 1: Completion of a bachelor's degree or equivalent coursework from a college or university accredited by any accrediting association recognized by the United Stated Department of Education --AND-- One (1) year of experience as a Juvenile Correctional Officer, Parole Agent, OR professional casework or group work experience which has included counseling and direct involvement in complex treatment assignments (e.g., probation officer, social worker, group counselor).

Applications will also be accepted from candidates currently enrolled and completing their last semester/quarter prior to graduating with a Bachelor's degree. A letter from the school indicating graduation date must be submitted with the application. Proof of degree conferred must be provided at time of hire.

--OR--

Option 2: Thirty (30) semester (45 quarter) units of completed college coursework in psychology, sociology, administration of justice or other closely related behavioral science; at least half of the required coursework must be upper division. --AND-- One (1) year of experience as described above.
Employment and/or vocational counseling experience is not qualifying.

Note: Applicants that do not possess a bachelor's degree must provide copies of transcripts (preferred) or a list of completed college coursework. Qualifying degrees or coursework must be completed at a college or university accredited by any accrediting association recognized by the United States Department of Education.

Degrees or coursework completed outside of the U.S. must be accompanied by an evaluation report from a reputable credential evaluation service indicating equivalency to degrees or coursework completed at a college or university accredited by any accrediting association recognized by the United States Department of Education.

 

Probation Officer III:

Education: A bachelor’s degree or equivalent coursework –OR- thirty (30) semester (45 quarter) units of completed college coursework in psychology, sociology, criminal justice, police science, or other closely related behavioral science, of which at least half must be upper division courses. (Unless a bachelor’s degree has been conferred, a list of completed college coursework or copies of transcripts must be submitted with the application.)

AND

Experience: Eighteen (18) months of experience as a journey-level probation officer. Probation Officer I experience is not considered qualifying and must be clearly distinguished on the application from journey-level Probation Officer (Probation Officer II) experience.

Note: An additional thirty (30) semester (45 quarter) units of graduate level coursework in psychology, sociology, criminology, or a closely related behavioral science may substitute for up to six (6) months of the required experience.

 

 

Who decides what questions are asked?

 

Probation Officer I and II:   We administer the Board of State and Community Corrections Probation Officer Examination for Local Corrections; the Board develops and determines the questions included.  

 

Probation Officer III:  The Human Resources Analyst works with the department’s Subject Matter Experts to develop questions used  in the examination.

 

 

When the testing is done?

 

Testing is done approximately 4 weeks after a recruitment closes.

 

 

How the testing is done, etc.?

 

The PO I/II test is administered in the Test Center; multiple choice/paper & pencil tests. 

 

The PO III test is a writing exercise administered at the ISD computer lab using MS Word.

 

 

I hope these help you.  Let me know if you have additional questions.  Thanks.

 

 

 

From: <jrr@ramzlaw.com> [mailto:jrr@ramzlaw.com]
Sent: Wednesday, September 16, 2015 12:34 PM
To: Windle, Bob - HR <BWindle@hr.sbcounty.gov>

Subject: Promotional Lists
Importance: High

 

Hello.

 

We are trying to get information into the promotional process.  Specifically, we are trying to figure out how does a need for a list come into being?  What are the qualifications?  Who decides what questions are asked?  When the testing is done?  How the testing is done, etc.?

 

The personnel rules are vague.

 

Please advise.

Message.subject: Re: Beers
Beers
Message.body:
In cases of uncertainty not removed by the preceding rules, the language of a contract should be interpreted most strongly against the party who caused the uncertainty to exist.
Cal. Civ. Code § 1654 (West)

Where employer drafted employment contract, employer was responsible for any ambiguity created by its use of language, and such ambiguous language was construed strictly against employer.  RKO Radio Pictures v. Sheridan, C.A.9 (Cal.)1952, 195 F.2d 167.Contracts   155

Best,

Manny Ruiz, Post-Bar Law Clerk

Message.subject: Your file has been downloaded
Beers
Message.body:
This is what I found on advertisements and job offers. Bold stuff is on point.

It is true that advertisements are not typically treated as offers, but merely as invitations to bargain. 1) Corbin on Contracts (1963) § 25, pp. 74–75; Rest.2d, Contracts, § 26, com. b, at p. 76.) There is, however, a fundamental exception to this rule: an advertisement can constitute an offer, and form the basis of a unilateral contract, if it calls for performance of a specific act without further communication and leaves nothing for further negotiation. (Lefkowitz v. Great Minneapolis Surplus Store (1957) 251 Minn. 188, 86 N.W.2d 689, 691; 1 Corbin on Contracts (1963) §§ 25, 64, pp. 75–76, 264–270; Rest.2d, Contracts, § 26, com. b, at p. 76.)

Harris v. Time, Inc., 191 Cal. App. 3d 449, 455, 237 Cal. Rptr. 584, 587 (Ct. App. 1987), as modified (May 21, 1987)

Thus, in simply publicizing an employment opportunity with N1H and inviting individuals to apply, MSC made no offer or promise that potential candidates could accept to form a contract. See Silverman, 472 A.2d at 112; Rofra, Inc. v. Bd. of Educ., Prince George's Cnty., 28 Md.App. 538, 346 A.2d 458, 459 (Md.Ct.Spec.App.1975) (“[A]n ordinary advertisement for bids or tenders is not itself an offer .... [A] contract is not formed until the lowest bid is in fact accepted.”); see also *438 Watson v. Pub. Serv. Co. of Colo., 207 P.3d 860, 868–69 (Colo.App.2008) (concluding that an internet job posting was an advertisement and thus not an offer by the employer that created an implied contract with the employee). To the extent there was an offer, it was made by Belyakov when he submitted an application. See Silverman, 472 A.2d at 112. Because MSC never accepted it, there was no contract

86 F.Supp.3d 430


Best,

Manny Ruiz, Post-Bar Law Clerk

Hey John,

Last few emails seemed kinda contentious. Did the payment get taken care of? If not the same card as before is adequate for payment. I am by no means asking you to work for free. On another note, I spoke with Natalie again (unfortunately) and she indicated that she saw the decree in June. She stated she was waiting for me. That leads me to believe that the final decree is somewhere between the attorneys. If that is the case, can we reach out to him? I am prepared to write the $2500 check indicated in the final we proposed. Please let me know. Thanks.

Mike

Message.subject: Beers, re: Appeal of the August 19, 2015 Application for Division Director I
Message.body:
Mr. DeBoer:

Per The County of San Bernardino Personnel Rules, Rule IV, Section 20, my client, Ms. Elizabeth Beers, would like to appeal the August 19, 2015, rejection of her Application for Division Director I based on not meeting the minimum qualifications (please see the attached).

Per Personnel Rules, Rule IV, Section 20, the client has until September 4, 2015, to resolve this complaint.  in the interim, my client and I are willing and able to meet to discuss the above, and attached.

Thank you for your time and consideration.
John R. Ramirez, Esq.
